resource.title: Teaching in Masks & Face Shields - An Experiment

slidetranscripts.slidetranscript:
<Document xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xmlns:xsd="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema"> <Content> <Block> <Span Text="During the COVID-19 pandemic, faculty had to change many of the ways they used to teach in the classroom to adapt to new policies and safety measures. As we return to a new sense of normalcy, it’s important to recognize that students and faculty will face new challenges and opportunities as they return to campus. Among these changes include new modalities of teaching, the requirement of teaching and learning with masks in the classroom, and new supplies you need to bring with you when you teach on campus. 
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="Click on the hands to learn more about each of these changes. 
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="When you have viewed all sections, a GO button will appear which will take you to a summary and a quiz for this section. " /> </Block> </Content> </Document>

<Document xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xmlns:xsd="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema"> <Content> <Block> <Span Text="Learning in a post COVID environment also brings new challenges for students. Click on each of the pictures to learn about the challenges you and your students will face and a few strategies to address each of them. 
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="When you’ve viewed each of the challenges and strategies, a BACK button will appear which will take you back to Teaching at HCC Post-COVID.
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="Personal Space
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="Because of the social distancing required during COVID-19, personal space bubbles may be a little larger than they were before. This means students may be a little more reluctant to sit as closely to one another and even you as the instructor may need to keep slightly more distance between you and your student. 
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="Avoid crowding by doors and laptop carts by calling on tables or rows to pick up resources or exit the classroom so students don’t all go to the same place at once.
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="To make sharing documents and collaborating on projects more comfortable, utilize digital tools such as Google Docs, Slides and Jamboard for collaboration and discussion. This way students can all view and edit the same document without needing to gather around one piece of paper. 
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="As instructors, we sometimes like to get close to students to offer our help. However, you can avoid hovering over students to see their work by asking them to share a copy with you online via Google Drive, take a picture and send it to you by email or submit work on Canvas so you can provide feedback. 
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="Click the X to return to Challenges and Strategies. 
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="Participation
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="Since masks may muffle students’ voices, they may need to speak a little louder than usual, which can make them more hesitant to participate and answer questions. 
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="To mitigate this issue, consider adding a backchannel chat to your classroom where students can type and send in their questions as messages. Tools like Padlet or Canvas Chat can facilitate a backchannel so you can address questions and comments as they come in or wait until a specific time to hold a Q&A session. 
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="Students may also be less likely to speak up and ask for clarification, so consider incorporating polling software like Poll Everywhere, Quizizz, or Socrative to check for understanding. These tools utilize cell phones or computers so that students can type their answers and answer anonymously to further lower the stakes of speaking up. 
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="And finally, where applicable, allow students to write or type their answers either digitally or on mini-whiteboards to gain more participation from the entire class while also allowing students to answer without pressing them to speak louder.
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="Click the X to return to Challenges and Strategies. 
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="Community
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="In addition to the increased personal space, masks further complicate the challenge of getting to know peers since students can’t see each other’s faces and it may be harder to hear and easier to misunderstand their classmates. Masks may also dampen some of the informal conversations that happen before, during and after class between students. 
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="Consider asking students to post a picture of themselves on Canvas without a mask so that you and their classmates can see what they look like. You may also consider asking students to post another picture with a mask so that you can associate what they look like with what you will see in the classroom.
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="Similarly, you may want to use a tool like VoiceThread or Flipgrid to have students create introductory videos without a mask and tell the class a little about themselves. At the end of the video, ask students to put on their mask so that you can also recognize them with their masks. Doing a video yourself with serve as a demo and let students get to know you without a mask as well.
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="In order to help build classroom community, consider building in activities to help students get to know each other. Have students collaborate either digitally or in person on assignments and projects and incorporate group work into each class meeting so that students have the chance to talk to at least one of their peers each class meeting. 
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="Click the X to return to Challenges and Strategies. " /> </Block> </Content> </Document>

<Document xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xmlns:xsd="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema"> <Content> <Block> <Span Text="At HCC, we have several different modalities, or ways of teaching. Click on each of the images to view more information about each modality. 
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="When you have viewed all of the modalities, a BACK button will appear which will take you back to Teaching at HCC Post-COVID.
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="Face-to-Face
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="In the face-to-face modality, classes meet in-person for the duration of the semester. Face-to-face classes DO use Canvas and should post content and assignments online for students to view and submit their work. In the face-to-face modality, faculty are able to provide and get immediate feedback to and from students, and it may be easier to build classroom community due to the proximity of students to one another and informal conversations that occur before, during and after class.
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="Click the X to return to Modalities of Teaching. 
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="Hybrid
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="In a hybrid class, faculty and students meet in-person once a week and have a weekly online component to substitute the 2nd day they would spend together in the face-to-face class. Most hybrid classes are 50-50, meaning half of the class is face-to-face and the other half is online, but some hybrid classes may meet just a few times a semester or at other intervals. Hybrid classes offer the benefits of a face-to-face class with the additional flexibility of being able to do the rest of the course work online.
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="To learn more about what a hybrid class looks like, click the link to view the ”What is a Hybrid?” video. You may also share this video with your students to help them know what to expect in your hybrid class. 
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="Click the X to return to Modalities of Teaching. 
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="Scheduled Remote
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="In a scheduled remote class, students meet with the faculty member at a scheduled time online using our video conferencing software Zoom. Zoom meetings can be scheduled in Canvas as recurring meetings so that you can use the same link throughout the semester and it will show up on the students’ “To-Do” list on Canvas. You can facilitate discussions and group activities using Zoom breakout rooms where small groups of students get sent off into their own sub-session of the meeting. You as the host of the meeting can pop in and out of breakout rooms as desired. Scheduled remote classes provide many of the same benefits of face-to-face classes without requiring students to come to campus. 
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="Click the X to return to Modalities of Teaching. 
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="Flexible Online
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="Flexible online classes are completely flexible and have NO scheduled meetings at all. All interaction is facilitated through Canvas and other online tools. Faculty teaching flexible online classes may still use Zoom for review sessions and student hours, but these sessions must be optional without penalty for students who do not attend. This modality is the most flexible option, allowing students to complete assignments and consume course material at the time of day that works best for them. 
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="Click the X to return to Modalities of Teaching. " /> </Block> </Content> </Document>

<Document xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xmlns:xsd="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema"> <Content> <Block> <Span Text="Does the material of the mask affect sound or comfort more?
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="Click STUDY to refer back to the study or click SUBMIT to check your answer." /> </Block> </Content> </Document>

<Document xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xmlns:xsd="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema"> <Content> <Block> <Style Justification="Left" /> <Span Text="True or False: You don’t know how your mask fits until you speak for a while with it on. 
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="Click STUDY to refer back to the study or click SUBMIT to check your answer." /> </Block> </Content> </Document>

<Document xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xmlns:xsd="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema"> <Content> <Block> <Span Text="True or False: Professors in the study found face shields are far preferable to masks for speaking. 
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style Justification="Left" /> <Span Text="Click STUDY to refer back to the study or click SUBMIT to check your answer." /> </Block> </Content> </Document>

<Document xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xmlns:xsd="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema"> <Content> <Block> <Span Text="Summary
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="Teaching with masks does not have a one-size-fits-all solution. Test out different types of masks to find what’s most comfortable for you. 
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="Make sure to bring extra masks so that you can switch between them if it gets too hot or wet while teaching. Having a couple fresh masks will make it more comfortable to teach longer class periods. 
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="While the professors in the study found that face shields are not the holy grail, they still may serve a purpose in classes where facial expressions are essential to learning. 
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="Finally, experiment and practice teaching with your mask on to find what works best for you! Don’t let the first day of class be the first day you try teaching with a mask! 
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="Click BACK to return to the Teaching at HCC Post-COVID slide. " /> </Block> </Content> </Document>

<Document xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xmlns:xsd="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema"> <Content> <Block> <Span Text="There are several supplies that you may want to bring with you when you teach on campus. 
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="Drag and drop the items into the bag to learn more about how each plays an important role in your teacher toolkit.
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="Once an item has been placed in the toolkit, you can click on the bag itself to review any viewed item. 
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="When you have placed all of the items in the bag, a BACK button will appear which will take you back to the Teaching at HCC Post-COVID slide. 
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="Drag and drop an item into the bag to get started. 
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="Markers
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="Whiteboard markers will NOT be supplied in the classroom so it’s important that you bring your own markers to each class you teach. Don’t forget to bring an eraser or cloth to clear the board at the end of a section or class. You may also consider bringing extra markers for students to use if you’d like them to complete activities on the whiteboard. 
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="Click the X to return to your teacher toolkit. 
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="Masks
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="Bring extra masks so you can switch masks if one gets too hot or moist from speaking – especially if you teach longer sessions. Be sure to test out different types of masks, including both cloth and disposable, to find out which type is most comfortable to you. 
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="Click the X to return to your teacher toolkit. 
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="Pens
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="Consider packing extra pens that you can give to students if they forget to bring one of their own. This will cut down on students sharing their own supplies and limit the need to disrupt other students by asking to borrow a pen. You may consider giving these pens away or wiping them down at the end of the session if you choose to have students return them to you. 
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="Click the X to return to your teacher toolkit. 
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="Water
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="You, and your students, are allowed to take a sip of water during class by pulling your mask down temporarily to drink. Once you finish, replace the mask so that it fits securely over your mouth and nose. However, eating is NOT permitted inside the classroom. If a student needs to eat, please ask them to leave the classroom to do so. The student should either go outside the building or to a designated eating area for safety. 
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="Click the X to return to your teacher toolkit. 
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="Sanitizer
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="Hand sanitizer will be available in the hallways outside the classroom. Remind students to use hand sanitizer every time they enter and exit the room. You may also consider bringing your own sanitizer with aloe or lotion to prevent dryness. 
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="Click the X to return to your teacher toolkit. 
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="Bag
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="These are the items in your bag. Click on an item to view the information again. or click the X to return to your teacher toolkit. 
" /> </Block> <Block /> </Content> </Document>

<Document xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xmlns:xsd="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema"> <Content> <Block> <Span Text="Using a mask is an important safety precaution for preventing the spread of COVID-19. While teaching in a mask does have its disadvantages, wearing a mask is required for both faculty and students while in the classroom and inside buildings on campus. 
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="Face shields may be a good alternative in disciplines like language where seeing facial expressions is important to the learning process. However, masks are still strongly encouraged and faculty may switch between wearing a face shield and a mask depending on the activity. 
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="The most important way to prepare yourself to teach with a mask is to practice! Try giving a 5 to 10 minute lesson while wearing a mask so that you get comfortable with the feeling and experiment with what works best. 
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="Recording yourself or practicing with a friend or family member can provide feedback so that you can adjust your teaching style to be as clear and understandable as possible while wearing your mask. 
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="Click GO to learn more. " /> </Block> </Content> </Document>

<Document xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xmlns:xsd="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema"> <Content> <Block> <Span Text="Which modality does not meet at all in real time? 
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="Select your answer, then click SUBMIT." /> </Block> </Content> </Document>

<Document xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xmlns:xsd="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema"> <Content> <Block> <Span Text="Which of the following is the BEST way to make sure students are understanding content in a F2F class? 
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="Select your answer, then click SUBMIT." /> </Block> </Content> </Document>

<Document xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xmlns:xsd="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema"> <Content> <Block> <Style Justification="Left" /> <Span Text="Which of the following should you bring with you each class to keep you safe and comfortable? 
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style Justification="Left" /> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style Justification="Left" /> <Span Text="Select your answer, then click SUBMIT." /> </Block> </Content> </Document>

<Document xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xmlns:xsd="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema"> <Content> <Block> <Span Text="Congratulations!
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="You have completed this section of the New Faculty Crash Course! 
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="Click GO to view the next section on Adult Learning Theory! 
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="Try Again
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="Click the RETRY button to take the quiz again. You must get at least 60% to pass. " /> </Block> </Content> </Document>

<Document xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xmlns:xsd="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema"> <Content> <Block> <Span Text="Community college students are a diverse population and include students from all ethnicities, backgrounds, ages, abilities, and socio-economic statuses. Students attend community college for a variety of reasons and while many go on to pursue a 4-year degree, community colleges offer many different types of programs such as career track associate degrees, certificates and continuing education classes. 
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="However, the one thing all community college students share is that they are adult learners. Each of your students will enter your classroom with unique experience, skills and needs, but they all should be treated and taught as adults. 
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="In this section, we will learn about the demographics of a community college and how those demographics may affect your teaching approach. Then we’ll explore 4 principles of adult learning that will help you better engage your students and teach adult learners more effectively. 
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="Click GO to get started. " /> </Block> </Content> </Document>

<Document xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xmlns:xsd="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema"> <Content> <Block> <Span Text="“By keeping the doors to higher education wide open, community colleges have accepted the responsibility for educating all their students, including those who are not ready to do college-level work” – Deepa Rao
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="Community colleges in the United States have an “Open Door” policy which means that anyone who wants to study at a community college can do so by filling out the application and providing a copy of a high school diploma or GED certificate. 
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="But what does this mean for you? 
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="During your time teaching at HCC, you will get students who are taking developmental classes, students with disabilities, military veterans, non-traditional students returning to school and, of course, you will see some traditional-aged students who have just graduated high school. Keep in mind that even though all of your students are in college, not all of your students have been well-prepared to do college-level work. Sharing study strategies and getting to know students individually to find out their strengths and weaknesses can help your students build skills not just for your discipline but for their entire college career. 
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="Now let’s learn more about community college students by playing a game!
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="Click GO to continue. " /> </Block> </Content> </Document>

<Document xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xmlns:xsd="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema"> <Content> <Block> <Span Text="Let’s play the Percent is Right!
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="You will be asked a series of questions about community college student demographics. 
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="Decide on a number or percentage to answer each question and type it in the given field. 
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="Get as close as you can to the right number without going over. 
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="When you’re ready to start, click PLAY to begin. " /> </Block> </Content> </Document>

<Document xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xmlns:xsd="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema"> <Content> <Block> <Span Text="How old is the average HCC student?
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="Type your answer in the yellow box, then click SUBMIT. 
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="Correct (REMOVE)
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="Although the average age of an HCC student is 26, this means that you may have students who are significantly younger and older than 26. HCC’s dual enrollment program “JumpStart” works with local high schools to allow high school students to attend classes both at HCC and taught in high schools by HCC instructors, so you may see students as young as 16 in your classes. However, even though they may be younger than the average student, they are still considered adults and have the same rights as other students at HCC including FERPA protection and the right and opportunity to view and discuss “college-level” material. Essentially, even though students may still be in high school, they alone have the right to view and discuss their grades with their instructor, not their parents. For more information on FERPA, click the link in the resources tab to view the “Are you FERPA-red” training. 
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="On the other hand, you may also have students who are changing careers or auditing classes in their retirement. These students may be significantly older than 26 and may be able to provide a wealth of first hand experience and knowledge to share with the rest of the class. However, it’s always best to test the waters with them first before assuming that they can contribute to the conversation. Some older students may be self-conscious about returning to the classroom when everyone else seems to be younger than they are. Always get to know your students first and ask questions to the entire class if you aren’t sure whether or not a student wants to share their experience. 
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="Click GO to view the next question. " /> </Block> </Content> </Document>

<Document xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xmlns:xsd="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema"> <Content> <Block> <Span Text="What percent of students study part-time at HCC?
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="Type your answer in the yellow box, then click SUBMIT. 
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="Correct (REMOVE)
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="65.4% of students study part-time at HCC. This means more than half of students have additional obligations such as working part-time or full-time jobs and taking care of children, siblings or elderly parents. This may not greatly impact the way that you teach your students, but it may impact when, where and how your students learn outside the classroom. It is much more difficult to read when you are tired after working a full shift or frequently interrupted by the needs of others. Understanding and empathizing with students who are in this situation may encourage you to incorporate more flexibility into strict deadlines or attempt to communicate more with students who are missing assignments or not attending class. We should be clear however, that students are signing up for rigorous, college-level courses and their own personal circumstances do not change the material or the due dates in your syllabus. Although you cannot make your course less challenging for students who have additional obligations, you may want to set expectations at the beginning of the semester and ask students to talk to you if they do have extenuating circumstances that will affect their attendance or performance in your class. Providing a little leniency for students who let you know they will not be able to complete certain assignments at a given time or date may be acceptable if you are advised before the assignment is due. 
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="Click GO to view the next question. " /> </Block> </Content> </Document>

<Document xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xmlns:xsd="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema"> <Content> <Block> <Span Text="What percent of students at HCC are international students? 
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="Type your answer in the yellow box, then click SUBMIT. 
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="Correct (REMOVE)
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="13% of students at HCC are international students. 1 in 10 of students in your classroom may have grown up in a different culture and speaking a different language. This does not mean they should receive less rigorous coursework, but it does change the amount of effort they may need to put into something that could be a simple task for an American student who is familiar with the US college system and norms. Students from other cultures may also have different expectations about the roles of the teacher and the student. In some cultures, students are expected to be quiet and take notes while the teacher lectures and may be confused or hesitant when asked to participate in active learning activities. Explaining why you are doing certain activities the way you are doing them may help alleviate hesitation and provide clearer expectations of how students should behave in your class. 
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="Click GO to view the next question. " /> </Block> </Content> </Document>

<Document xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xmlns:xsd="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema"> <Content> <Block> <Span Text="What percentage of the Howard county population does not speak English as their native language at home? 
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="Type your answer in the yellow box, then click SUBMIT. 
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="Correct (REMOVE)
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="25.2% of the Howard county population does not speak English as their native language at home. While not all of our students come from Howard county, HCC does serve this population and you may have several students in your classes for whom English is their second, third or even forth language. These students may need additional support understanding directions, assignments and course material and can benefit from closed captioning on videos and clear instructions. Reading a chapter of a textbook may take double the time it would take a native English speaker and their writing may not be as strong as other students’. Again, the goal is not to lessen the rigor of your course material, but empathizing with students and giving them tips on how to read and study in your discipline may make a huge difference in their workload and effort needed to be successful. When evaluating assignments, if writing is not the main objective, you may consider overlooking some simple spelling or grammatical errors as long as they do not affect the overall intelligibility of the assignment. 
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="Click GO to view the next question. " /> </Block> </Content> </Document>

<Document xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xmlns:xsd="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema"> <Content> <Block> <Span Text="For the last activity in our game, you will be asked to match the numbers on the right, to form the correct percentage of each community college demographic on the left. 
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="Drag and drop the numbers into the slots to form 2 digit percentages for each demographic. 
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="Then click SUBMIT to check your answers. 
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="Correct (REMOVE)
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="While some of them may be surprising, the exact percentage of students in each of these demographics is less important than understanding that community colleges serve all of these types of students. First generation students may be more motivated than the average student, but may also have less support from family, additional responsibilities and fewer role models they can look to for encouragement and advice. Single parents not only have the added responsibilities of full-time or part-time work, but also must work around their children’s schedules including daycare, sick days and school holidays, not to mention parenting duties like cooking and helping their children with their homework. Veteran students may be excellent students but may have additional duties and responsibilities with the military and may have different motivations and goals for attending college. Community colleges also open their doors to students with disabilities which bring a wide range of challenges and opportunities including meeting required accommodations such as closed captioning for videos, extra time on tests and assignments, materials in alternative formats and interpreters in the classroom. See the Accommodations Memo presentation in the Resources tab to learn more about your responsibilities and how you can support students with disabilities. And finally, many students may be attending community college to pursue a new career or gain new skills they can use to be promoted at their current place of employment. Students with Bachelor’s degrees enter your classroom well-prepared to do college-level work and may speed through assignments or require additional support as they unlearn certain skills or behaviors they picked up through experience. 
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="Overall, your classroom will be made up of a diverse set of students that will change each semester. As an instructor at a community college, you should practice flexibility, understanding and try to get to know each of your students without any assumptions of who they are or what their situation is. Each student, even within the same demographic, may have a completely different situation and while it’s not your responsibility to water down your content, you should try to meet each student wherever they are and support them as best as you can. This may mean allowing students an extra day to turn in an assignment or providing the opportunity to redo it with additional feedback and guidance. 
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="Now let’s take a look at some strategies you can use to effectively teach adult learners. 
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="Click GO to continue. " /> </Block> </Content> </Document>

<Document xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xmlns:xsd="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema"> <Content> <Block> <Span Text="Malcolm Knowles was one of the most famous educators who studied adult learning and coined the term “Andragogy”, which is a combination of pedagogy and adult, meaning the practice of teaching adults. Although Knowles has many important books, theories and research, let’s look at just four of the principles he used to define adult learning and how they impact adult learners. 
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="Click on the tabs to learn more about each principle. 
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="When you have viewed all of the tabs, a GO button will appear which you can use to view a summary and test your understanding with a short quiz on this section. 
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="Involvement
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style Justification="Left" /> <Span Text="Adult learners want to be involved in their learning process and the planning and evaluation of instruction. They want to be able to make decisions about how they learn, when they learn and what they learn. In order to involve students in the learning process, incorporate choice into your assignments and materials to give adult learners more agency and ask students for feedback on how their learning is going and what changes can be made it make the class more effective. Explain why you are doing things the way you are doing them and why specific content is taught. 
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style Justification="Left" /> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style Justification="Left" /> <Span Text="Experience
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style Justification="Left" /> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style Justification="Left" /> <Span Text="One of the major differences between teaching children and teaching adults is that adults come into the classroom with a wide range of experiences that can be drastically different from one another. Fortunately, you as an instructor can leverage this experience to put the subject matter into context your students can understand which can be beneficial for all students in the classroom. Before explaining a topic or concept, check with students to see what they already know about the subject. How far can they go on their own? Once you find the limit of their knowledge or gaps in their understanding, build from that point instead of starting from scratch. And you don’t have to do all the work! Ask students to come up with their own examples of concepts or similar situations that they may have encountered in their lives.
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style Justification="Left" /> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style Justification="Left" /> <Span Text="Relevance
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style Justification="Left" /> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style Justification="Left" /> <Span Text="Adult learners are most interested in learning topics that they can put into practice right away. Adult learners want to know why the content matters and how it will help them in their everyday lives, either at work or personally. To help adult learners find relevance, explain connections between content and real-world situations. Similarly, ground content in real-world examples to establish how professionals in your discipline need the skill or knowledge to be successful. You can also ask students to find their own relevance in your content by challenging students to reflect on how your material relates to their own personal or professional lives. 
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style Justification="Left" /> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style Justification="Left" /> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style Justification="Left" /> <Span Text="Problem-Centered
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style Justification="Left" /> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style Justification="Left" /> <Span Text="Adult learners respond better when learning material to solve a problem instead of learning it for the sake of the content or curriculum. Framing your content in the context of a problem can provide both relevance and real-world situations while also asking learners to rely on their prior experience to attempt to solve the problem. Using techniques like case-studies and scenarios can present course concepts in a more meaningful and engaging way while also establishing relevance. Give learners a chance to attempt to solve the problem before providing instruction or guidance. Research on prediction shows that students are more receptive to receiving instruction when they have struggled first themselves and this can also help students identify gaps in their own knowledge which further establishes a sense of urgency and relevance as they “need to know” this information. " /> </Block> </Content> </Document>

<Document xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xmlns:xsd="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema"> <Content> <Block> <Span Text="True or False: All community college students should be treated as adults, regardless of their age" /> <Span Text="." /> <Span Text=" " /> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="Select your answer, then click SUBMIT." /> </Block> </Content> </Document>

<Document xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xmlns:xsd="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema"> <Content> <Block> <Span Text="In this section, you will learn about 3 important pedagogical concepts that will help you ensure that you are meeting your course objectives, balance technology use, pedagogy and content knowledge effectively, and reach and engage all of your students.
