<Document xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xmlns:xsd="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema"> <Content> <Block> <Style LineSpacingRule="Single" LineSpacing="20" SpacingAfter="0" /> <Span Text="Summary
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style LineSpacingRule="Single" LineSpacing="20" SpacingAfter="0" /> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style LeadingMargin="0" FirstLineMargin="0" LineSpacingRule="Single" LineSpacing="20" SpacingAfter="0"> <ListStyle ListType="None" BulletChar="•" BulletFont="Arial"> <BulletPicture Size="0x0" /> </ListStyle> </Style> <Span Text="Backward Design is a planning method for college courses" /> <Span Text=" and can help you plan curriculum, courses or individual lessons and activities.
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style LeadingMargin="0" FirstLineMargin="0" LineSpacingRule="Single" LineSpacing="20" SpacingAfter="0"> <ListStyle ListType="None" BulletChar="•" BulletFont="Arial"> <BulletPicture Size="0x0" /> </ListStyle> </Style> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style LeadingMargin="0" FirstLineMargin="0" LineSpacingRule="Single" LineSpacing="20" SpacingAfter="0"> <ListStyle ListType="None" BulletChar="•" BulletFont="Arial"> <BulletPicture Size="0x0" /> </ListStyle> </Style> <Span Text="The 3 steps of Backward Design are identifying your objectives, designing assessments that will provide evidence of students’ ability to meet those objectives and creating learning activities that will give students the information and practice they need to perform well on those assessments. 
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style LeadingMargin="0" FirstLineMargin="0" LineSpacingRule="Single" LineSpacing="20" SpacingAfter="0"> <ListStyle ListType="None" BulletChar="•" BulletFont="Arial"> <BulletPicture Size="0x0" /> </ListStyle> </Style> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style LeadingMargin="0" FirstLineMargin="0" LineSpacingRule="Single" LineSpacing="20" SpacingAfter="0"> <ListStyle ListType="None" BulletChar="•" BulletFont="Arial"> <BulletPicture Size="0x0" /> </ListStyle> </Style> <Span Text="Objectives should be clear and assessments should be authentic. An authentic assessment mimics what students would actually do with the information or skills in the real-world. How would you use the skill or knowledge within your discipline and how would you know you’re doing it well? 
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style LeadingMargin="0" FirstLineMargin="0" LineSpacingRule="Single" LineSpacing="20" SpacingAfter="0"> <ListStyle ListType="None" BulletChar="•" BulletFont="Arial"> <BulletPicture Size="0x0" /> </ListStyle> </Style> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style LeadingMargin="0" FirstLineMargin="0" LineSpacingRule="Single" LineSpacing="20" SpacingAfter="0"> <ListStyle ListType="None" BulletChar="•" BulletFont="Arial"> <BulletPicture Size="0x0" /> </ListStyle> </Style> <Span Text="Your textbook can and should play an important role in your course, but you don’t need to follow its organization or use it in its entirety for it to be useful. Identify what your textbook does well and leverage it for that, but if there are gaps or additional information or skills not covered in there, make sure to add those into your course in other ways such as supplementary materials, videos, projects or practice assignments. 
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style LeadingMargin="0" FirstLineMargin="0" LineSpacingRule="Single" LineSpacing="20" SpacingAfter="0"> <ListStyle ListType="None" BulletChar="•" BulletFont="Arial"> <BulletPicture Size="0x0" /> </ListStyle> </Style> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style LeadingMargin="0" FirstLineMargin="0" LineSpacingRule="Single" LineSpacing="20" SpacingAfter="0"> <ListStyle ListType="None" BulletChar="•" BulletFont="Arial"> <BulletPicture Size="0x0" /> </ListStyle> </Style> <Span Text="Backward Design is NOT a linear process and you may go back and forth between your objectives, assessments and activities frequently in order to make strong connections between each of them. This is a natural part of course design and revision and review can help you make stronger connections and more relevant assessments and assignments! 
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style LeadingMargin="0" FirstLineMargin="0" LineSpacingRule="Single" LineSpacing="20" SpacingAfter="0"> <ListStyle ListType="None" BulletChar="•" BulletFont="Arial"> <BulletPicture Size="0x0" /> </ListStyle> </Style> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style LineSpacingRule="Single" LineSpacing="20" SpacingAfter="0" /> <Span Text="Click BACK to return to the Pedagogical Concepts slide. " /> </Block> </Content> </Document>

<Document xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xmlns:xsd="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema"> <Content> <Block> <Span Text="Imagine you have just printed out a 4-page document and wanted to keep the papers together. Which technology would you choose to make sure your papers stayed together?
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="While all of the technologies pictured on this slide could achieve your purpose, you might have selected one or two clear choices over the others. Yes, maple syrup would technically get the job done, but it may cause other unintended consequences, like not being able to pull the papers apart neatly or having your document invaded by hungry ants. 
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="It’s the same principle when it comes to teaching technologies. While some options may technically get the job done, they may make the task more difficult or have unintended consequences. 
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="In this section, we will explore a pedagogical framework called TPACK which will help you balance when to use technology and help you decide which technology to use to meet your learning objectives. 
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="Click GO to learn more. " /> </Block> </Content> </Document>

<Document xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xmlns:xsd="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema"> <Content> <Block> <Span Text="The TPACK framework consists of Technology, Pedagogy and Content Knowledge and describes the transactional relationship and overlaps between these three areas. 
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="The TPACK framework is less a prescription of how to find and use technology and more of a strategic way to think about the purpose of technology and how it can influence your teaching methods, your content and students’ learning process. 
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="TPACK is the intersection of the appropriate use of technology, good teaching practices and expert-level content knowledge. The center of these three circles symbolizes the ideal teaching approach that balances these three areas appropriately and is neither too heavy on any one of these areas nor does it leave any of them out. 
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="In addition to the relation of the areas of TPACK, there are also overlaps between each circle that can also be helpful in understanding the relationships within the framework. 
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="The overlap of Technology and Content Knowledge challenges us to think about how technology can be used to present content but also to think about how our content may change as new technologies evolve. 
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="The overlap of Technology and Pedagogy asks us to consider how technology can be used to teach but also that as we incorporate new technologies into our classes, we must also teach our students how to use these technologies efficiently and effectively. 
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="And finally the overlap of Pedagogy and Content Knowledge reminds us that we should not only stay up-to-date with our own subject matter, but also with the evolving research of teaching and learning and use best practices to present our content and help our students learn and practice it. The flip side of this relationship asks us to remember that many of our students are new to studying our discipline and can benefit from our experience using discipline-specific strategies to read, study, and think within the subject area. We should help our students think like a mathematician or read like a biologist. 
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="Click GO to learn more about how you can use the TPACK framework to evaluate and select technologies for classroom use." /> </Block> </Content> </Document>

<Document xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xmlns:xsd="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema"> <Content> <Block> <Span Text="A quick Google search for teaching technologies will present you with an array of tools with shiny new features that you may be tempted to incorporate into your classes to increase engagement and make learning more fun. While you can always reach out to the staff at the Center for Teaching Excellence for guidance, what can we take from the TPACK framework to help us select and use technology effectively in the classroom?
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="First, all technology use should have a clear purpose and relate back to at least one objective or learning goal. Technology should never be used just for the sake of “trying something new” or for the sole purpose of making the class fun. Having fun in class is not a bad thing, but it shouldn’t be the main reason you’re using a new tool. Your technologies should accomplish a part of helping you meet your objectives whether it’s presenting content, low-stakes assessment, communicating with students or facilitating group work. We’ll explore some of the different technologies you can use to do these things in the next section on Teaching Technologies, but for now, it’s important to make sure whatever the technology is, it’s pulling its weight in helping you and your students meet the course objectives.
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="In some disciplines there are specific technologies or tools that professionals use in the field that students may benefit from using. Giving students experience with real-world technologies can give them a leg-up when applying for jobs or internships. In addition to technical tools, popular technologies and software used for communication or office tasks may also benefit students who learn to use them in college. Professional communication apps like Slack or Jira may be useful for students to start using before they get to the workplace and other tools like the Microsoft Office Suite or Google App Suite can be essential skills for students entering the workforce. If there are certain tools you frequently use in the discipline that lend themselves to student-use in your class, it can be a great benefit to students to start using these tools now rather than learn it when they get hired. 
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="It’s important to mention that learning new technologies isn’t always straightforward and simple. Some technologies are very complex and while they may have some strong benefits, there is a steep learning curve to get you up and running. It’s important to be realistic with the time you have to dedicate to learning a new technology and if it’s going to take you hours and hours to learn how to use it effectively, the benefit of using that technology had better be worth it! 
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="Besides the time it takes you to learn the tool, you should also be prepared to teach students how to use the tool if they are going to be expected to use it themselves. Some tools, like presentation software, may not be necessary to teach students how to use if it’s mainly to present content to them, however, if students are expected to use the technology to complete an assignment or practice a skill, they may require training and guidance to be successful. Fortunately, there are many video tutorials for how to use most technologies online on YouTube and you can also create your own tutorials or demonstrate how to use the tool to students, but you should be prepared to answer questions about the technology or help troubleshoot if something isn’t behaving as expected for students. The Center for Teaching Excellence can support you by creating instructional documentation for students and even visiting your classroom (in person or online) to give guided instructions or answer questions if that would be helpful to you and your students. 
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="The Learning Commons is also available to help students with questions about technology needed to complete assignments. Students can contact LC@howardcc.edu for help and Learning Commons staff will set up a time to meet with a student by phone or Zoom or provide assistance via email. 
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="Click BACK to return to the Pedagogical Concepts slide. 
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text=" 
" /> </Block> <Block /> </Content> </Document>

<Document xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xmlns:xsd="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema"> <Content> <Block> <Style FlowDirection="LeftToRight" LeadingMargin="0" TrailingMargin="0" FirstLineMargin="0" Justification="Left" CustomTabStops="" LineSpacingRule="Single" LineSpacing="20" SpacingBefore="0" SpacingAfter="0"> <ListStyle ListType="None" ListTypeFormat="Parentheses" Color="#000000" BulletFont="Arial" /> </Style> <Span Text="Universal Design for Learning (or UDL) is an approach to teaching that strives to level the playing field and give all learners the opportunity to succeed. It encourages us to teach in ways that appeals to different learning preferences and use multiple strategies and methods to help students meet the learning objectives. 
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style FlowDirection="LeftToRight" LeadingMargin="0" TrailingMargin="0" FirstLineMargin="0" Justification="Left" CustomTabStops="" LineSpacingRule="Single" LineSpacing="20" SpacingBefore="0" SpacingAfter="0"> <ListStyle ListType="None" ListTypeFormat="Parentheses" Color="#000000" BulletFont="Arial" /> </Style> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style FlowDirection="LeftToRight" LeadingMargin="0" TrailingMargin="0" FirstLineMargin="0" Justification="Left" CustomTabStops="" LineSpacingRule="Single" LineSpacing="20" SpacingBefore="0" SpacingAfter="0"> <ListStyle ListType="None" ListTypeFormat="Parentheses" Color="#000000" BulletFont="Arial" /> </Style> <Span Text="Within UDL, there are 3 main areas that provide guidelines for how to best reach your students. These 3 pillars are Engagement, Representation, and Expression. 
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style FlowDirection="LeftToRight" LeadingMargin="0" TrailingMargin="0" FirstLineMargin="0" Justification="Left" CustomTabStops="" LineSpacingRule="Single" LineSpacing="20" SpacingBefore="0" SpacingAfter="0"> <ListStyle ListType="None" ListTypeFormat="Parentheses" Color="#000000" BulletFont="Arial" /> </Style> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style FlowDirection="LeftToRight" LeadingMargin="0" TrailingMargin="0" FirstLineMargin="0" Justification="Left" CustomTabStops="" LineSpacingRule="Single" LineSpacing="20" SpacingBefore="0" SpacingAfter="0"> <ListStyle ListType="None" ListTypeFormat="Parentheses" Color="#000000" BulletFont="Arial" /> </Style> <Span Text="Click on the images to view more information about each area. 
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style FlowDirection="LeftToRight" LeadingMargin="0" TrailingMargin="0" FirstLineMargin="0" Justification="Left" CustomTabStops="" LineSpacingRule="Single" LineSpacing="20" SpacingBefore="0" SpacingAfter="0"> <ListStyle ListType="None" ListTypeFormat="Parentheses" Color="#000000" BulletFont="Arial" /> </Style> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style FlowDirection="LeftToRight" LeadingMargin="0" TrailingMargin="0" FirstLineMargin="0" Justification="Left" CustomTabStops="" LineSpacingRule="Single" LineSpacing="20" SpacingBefore="0" SpacingAfter="0"> <ListStyle ListType="None" ListTypeFormat="Parentheses" Color="#000000" BulletFont="Arial" /> </Style> <Span Text="You can also click the link at the bottom of the screen to visit the CAST website which provides an even more thorough overview of what each of these areas are and how you can use them to help your students learn. 
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style FlowDirection="LeftToRight" LeadingMargin="0" TrailingMargin="0" FirstLineMargin="0" Justification="Left" CustomTabStops="" LineSpacingRule="Single" LineSpacing="20" SpacingBefore="0" SpacingAfter="0"> <ListStyle ListType="None" ListTypeFormat="Parentheses" Color="#000000" BulletFont="Arial" /> </Style> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style FlowDirection="LeftToRight" LeadingMargin="0" TrailingMargin="0" FirstLineMargin="0" Justification="Left" CustomTabStops="" LineSpacingRule="Single" LineSpacing="20" SpacingBefore="0" SpacingAfter="0"> <ListStyle ListType="None" ListTypeFormat="Parentheses" Color="#000000" BulletFont="Arial" /> </Style> <Span Text="When you have viewed all 3 of the UDL areas, a BACK button will appear on this slide that will take you back to the Pedagogical Concepts slide. 
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style FlowDirection="LeftToRight" LeadingMargin="0" TrailingMargin="0" FirstLineMargin="0" Justification="Left" CustomTabStops="" LineSpacingRule="Single" LineSpacing="20" SpacingBefore="0" SpacingAfter="0"> <ListStyle ListType="None" ListTypeFormat="Parentheses" Color="#000000" BulletFont="Arial" /> </Style> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style FlowDirection="LeftToRight" LeadingMargin="0" TrailingMargin="0" FirstLineMargin="0" Justification="Left" CustomTabStops="" LineSpacingRule="Single" LineSpacing="20" SpacingBefore="0" SpacingAfter="0"> <ListStyle ListType="None" ListTypeFormat="Parentheses" Color="#000000" BulletFont="Arial" /> </Style> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style FlowDirection="LeftToRight" LeadingMargin="0" TrailingMargin="0" FirstLineMargin="0" Justification="Left" CustomTabStops="" LineSpacingRule="Single" LineSpacing="20" SpacingBefore="0" SpacingAfter="0"> <ListStyle ListType="None" ListTypeFormat="Parentheses" Color="#000000" BulletFont="Arial" /> </Style> <Span Text="Engagement
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style FlowDirection="LeftToRight" LeadingMargin="0" TrailingMargin="0" FirstLineMargin="0" Justification="Left" CustomTabStops="" LineSpacingRule="Single" LineSpacing="20" SpacingBefore="0" SpacingAfter="0"> <ListStyle ListType="None" ListTypeFormat="Parentheses" Color="#000000" BulletFont="Arial" /> </Style> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style FlowDirection="LeftToRight" LeadingMargin="0" TrailingMargin="0" FirstLineMargin="0" Justification="Left" CustomTabStops="" LineSpacingRule="Single" LineSpacing="20" SpacingBefore="0" SpacingAfter="0"> <ListStyle ListType="None" ListTypeFormat="Parentheses" Color="#000000" BulletFont="Arial" /> </Style> <Span Text="Engagement in UDL is all about the WHY of learning. In order to engage all of your students, it’s important to first establish relevance in what you are teaching. If you think back on our discussion on adult learning theory, you will remember that establishing relevance is also a key part of teaching adult learners effectively. Students want to know why they are learning the content and how it will impact their personal and professional lives. Beginning lectures and activities with real-world examples and helping your students make personal connections to your topic will set them up for greater success. 
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style FlowDirection="LeftToRight" LeadingMargin="0" TrailingMargin="0" FirstLineMargin="0" Justification="Left" CustomTabStops="" LineSpacingRule="Single" LineSpacing="20" SpacingBefore="0" SpacingAfter="0"> <ListStyle ListType="None" ListTypeFormat="Parentheses" Color="#000000" BulletFont="Arial" /> </Style> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style FlowDirection="LeftToRight" LeadingMargin="0" TrailingMargin="0" FirstLineMargin="0" Justification="Left" CustomTabStops="" LineSpacingRule="Single" LineSpacing="20" SpacingBefore="0" SpacingAfter="0"> <ListStyle ListType="None" ListTypeFormat="Parentheses" Color="#000000" BulletFont="Arial" /> </Style> <Span Text="Next, it’s important to clearly express your objectives. What is it that you want students to do? You’ve already got them interested by establishing how the topic is relevant to them, but you need to also tell them what your expectations are and what skills or knowledge they will be able to demonstrate by the end of the lesson. This helps students focus on the important parts and distinguish between essential information and things that are nice to know, but not critical to the objective. 
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style FlowDirection="LeftToRight" LeadingMargin="0" TrailingMargin="0" FirstLineMargin="0" Justification="Left" CustomTabStops="" LineSpacingRule="Single" LineSpacing="20" SpacingBefore="0" SpacingAfter="0"> <ListStyle ListType="None" ListTypeFormat="Parentheses" Color="#000000" BulletFont="Arial" /> </Style> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style FlowDirection="LeftToRight" LeadingMargin="0" TrailingMargin="0" FirstLineMargin="0" Justification="Left" CustomTabStops="" LineSpacingRule="Single" LineSpacing="20" SpacingBefore="0" SpacingAfter="0"> <ListStyle ListType="None" ListTypeFormat="Parentheses" Color="#000000" BulletFont="Arial" /> </Style> <Span Text="Once you have established relevance and expressed your objectives, try to minimize distractions as much as you can. Usually when we think of distractions, laptops, cell phones and social media come to mind, however, in this case, distractions can take the form of unnecessary information, too many additional resources, and even the amount of links on a webpage. Whenever possible, limit your resources and reading to the essential information and consider ways to simplify what your students see both in class and online. Taking the less is more approach for words and images on a PowerPoint slide can lower cognitive demand and make it easier for students to focus on what’s important. And when you are not using the presentation, blank the screen or turn off the projector to help students focus on the task at hand.
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style FlowDirection="LeftToRight" LeadingMargin="0" TrailingMargin="0" FirstLineMargin="0" Justification="Left" CustomTabStops="" LineSpacingRule="Single" LineSpacing="20" SpacingBefore="0" SpacingAfter="0"> <ListStyle ListType="None" ListTypeFormat="Parentheses" Color="#000000" BulletFont="Arial" /> </Style> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style FlowDirection="LeftToRight" LeadingMargin="0" TrailingMargin="0" FirstLineMargin="0" Justification="Left" CustomTabStops="" LineSpacingRule="Single" LineSpacing="20" SpacingBefore="0" SpacingAfter="0"> <ListStyle ListType="None" ListTypeFormat="Parentheses" Color="#000000" BulletFont="Arial" /> </Style> <Span Text="Another aspect of engagement is the encouragement you provide to your students. Let students know that you care about them and want them to succeed. It can be as simple as adding a positive message on assignment feedback or stating at the beginning of the semester both in your syllabus and in person, that you believe in your students and will work with them to help them succeed in your class. That doesn’t mean you’re going to make things easier for them, but if they work hard and put in the time and effort, you will do the same to help them learn and meet the objectives.
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style FlowDirection="LeftToRight" LeadingMargin="0" TrailingMargin="0" FirstLineMargin="0" Justification="Left" CustomTabStops="" LineSpacingRule="Single" LineSpacing="20" SpacingBefore="0" SpacingAfter="0"> <ListStyle ListType="None" ListTypeFormat="Parentheses" Color="#000000" BulletFont="Arial" /> </Style> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style FlowDirection="LeftToRight" LeadingMargin="0" TrailingMargin="0" FirstLineMargin="0" Justification="Left" CustomTabStops="" LineSpacingRule="Single" LineSpacing="20" SpacingBefore="0" SpacingAfter="0"> <ListStyle ListType="None" ListTypeFormat="Parentheses" Color="#000000" BulletFont="Arial" /> </Style> <Span Text="Finally, consider providing opportunities for self-assessment and reflection. Incorporate pauses for reflection in lectures and videos and build in self-assessment questions as part of your daily or weekly routine. Ask students to assess how they studied for your class as well as self-assess their understanding of the material. Giving students time and space to reflect and assess can help them think about their own learning process and open the door for conversation about study skills and approaches which will help them not only in your class, but for their entire college career. 
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style FlowDirection="LeftToRight" LeadingMargin="0" TrailingMargin="0" FirstLineMargin="0" Justification="Left" CustomTabStops="" LineSpacingRule="Single" LineSpacing="20" SpacingBefore="0" SpacingAfter="0"> <ListStyle ListType="None" ListTypeFormat="Parentheses" Color="#000000" BulletFont="Arial" /> </Style> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style FlowDirection="LeftToRight" LeadingMargin="0" TrailingMargin="0" FirstLineMargin="0" Justification="Left" CustomTabStops="" LineSpacingRule="Single" LineSpacing="20" SpacingBefore="0" SpacingAfter="0"> <ListStyle ListType="None" ListTypeFormat="Parentheses" Color="#000000" BulletFont="Arial" /> </Style> <Span Text="Click the X to return to the UDL slide. 
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style FlowDirection="LeftToRight" LeadingMargin="0" TrailingMargin="0" FirstLineMargin="0" Justification="Left" CustomTabStops="" LineSpacingRule="Single" LineSpacing="20" SpacingBefore="0" SpacingAfter="0"> <ListStyle ListType="None" ListTypeFormat="Parentheses" Color="#000000" BulletFont="Arial" /> </Style> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style FlowDirection="LeftToRight" LeadingMargin="0" TrailingMargin="0" FirstLineMargin="0" Justification="Left" CustomTabStops="" LineSpacingRule="Single" LineSpacing="20" SpacingBefore="0" SpacingAfter="0"> <ListStyle ListType="None" ListTypeFormat="Parentheses" Color="#000000" BulletFont="Arial" /> </Style> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style FlowDirection="LeftToRight" LeadingMargin="0" TrailingMargin="0" FirstLineMargin="0" Justification="Left" CustomTabStops="" LineSpacingRule="Single" LineSpacing="20" SpacingBefore="0" SpacingAfter="0"> <ListStyle ListType="None" ListTypeFormat="Parentheses" Color="#000000" BulletFont="Arial" /> </Style> <Span Text="Representation
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style FlowDirection="LeftToRight" LeadingMargin="0" TrailingMargin="0" FirstLineMargin="0" Justification="Left" CustomTabStops="" LineSpacingRule="Single" LineSpacing="20" SpacingBefore="0" SpacingAfter="0"> <ListStyle ListType="None" ListTypeFormat="Parentheses" Color="#000000" BulletFont="Arial" /> </Style> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style FlowDirection="LeftToRight" LeadingMargin="0" TrailingMargin="0" FirstLineMargin="0" Justification="Left" CustomTabStops="" LineSpacingRule="Single" LineSpacing="20" SpacingBefore="0" SpacingAfter="0"> <ListStyle ListType="None" ListTypeFormat="Parentheses" Color="#000000" BulletFont="Arial" /> </Style> <Span Text="Representation refers to the WHAT of learning. What are students learning and how is it being presented to them? 
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style FlowDirection="LeftToRight" LeadingMargin="0" TrailingMargin="0" FirstLineMargin="0" Justification="Left" CustomTabStops="" LineSpacingRule="Single" LineSpacing="20" SpacingBefore="0" SpacingAfter="0"> <ListStyle ListType="None" ListTypeFormat="Parentheses" Color="#000000" BulletFont="Arial" /> </Style> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style FlowDirection="LeftToRight" LeadingMargin="0" TrailingMargin="0" FirstLineMargin="0" Justification="Left" CustomTabStops="" LineSpacingRule="Single" LineSpacing="20" SpacingBefore="0" SpacingAfter="0"> <ListStyle ListType="None" ListTypeFormat="Parentheses" Color="#000000" BulletFont="Arial" /> </Style> <Span Text="The most common strategy for enhancing representation is varying your presentation methods. Offering audio alternatives for visual information and offering visual alternatives for auditory information can make your content more accessible to everyone. They key here is less about mixing materials, such as using visual materials one day and then auditory materials the next, but rather including both options in everything you do. This includes providing transcripts and captions for videos, and providing videos or audio clips that explain what’s written in text. It’s not always feasible to provide alternatives for every piece of content, assignment or communication, but being aware of which methods you are using and providing alternatives when it is feasible can help make your course more accessible to all of your students. 
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style FlowDirection="LeftToRight" LeadingMargin="0" TrailingMargin="0" FirstLineMargin="0" Justification="Left" CustomTabStops="" LineSpacingRule="Single" LineSpacing="20" SpacingBefore="0" SpacingAfter="0"> <ListStyle ListType="None" ListTypeFormat="Parentheses" Color="#000000" BulletFont="Arial" /> </Style> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style FlowDirection="LeftToRight" LeadingMargin="0" TrailingMargin="0" FirstLineMargin="0" Justification="Left" CustomTabStops="" LineSpacingRule="Single" LineSpacing="20" SpacingBefore="0" SpacingAfter="0"> <ListStyle ListType="None" ListTypeFormat="Parentheses" Color="#000000" BulletFont="Arial" /> </Style> <Span Text="Another representation strategy is clarifying symbols, keywords and acronyms that are commonly used in your discipline. Knowing these symbols and acronyms may greatly help students in their future careers, however, you should not expect that all students will come to your class knowing what they mean. This is especially true in math and hard sciences where specific vocabulary becomes second nature for those in the discipline but may not be as obvious to novice learners. Take UDL for example. To those of us who are familiar with this approach, the acronym is quite obvious. However, if you’ve never heard of Universal Design for Learning, UDL might sound strange and confusing. Taking time to clarify discipline specific symbols, keywords and acronyms can make it easier for students to focus on understanding the concept, rather than trying to decipher exactly what it is you’re talking about. If you aren’t sure whether your students know a specific keyword or acronym, ask for a volunteer to explain what it is. That way, you don’t need to repeat yourself every time and students may offer a new way to explain the word or symbol from the novice’s perspective rather than your expert explanation. 
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style FlowDirection="LeftToRight" LeadingMargin="0" TrailingMargin="0" FirstLineMargin="0" Justification="Left" CustomTabStops="" LineSpacingRule="Single" LineSpacing="20" SpacingBefore="0" SpacingAfter="0"> <ListStyle ListType="None" ListTypeFormat="Parentheses" Color="#000000" BulletFont="Arial" /> </Style> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style FlowDirection="LeftToRight" LeadingMargin="0" TrailingMargin="0" FirstLineMargin="0" Justification="Left" CustomTabStops="" LineSpacingRule="Single" LineSpacing="20" SpacingBefore="0" SpacingAfter="0"> <ListStyle ListType="None" ListTypeFormat="Parentheses" Color="#000000" BulletFont="Arial" /> </Style> <Span Text="Highlighting patterns, big ideas and relationships is a common teaching strategy that many teachers already use. Instead of teaching various distinct concepts, help students make connections between topics by revealing patterns and relationships among them. You can even ask students to attempt to make connections as an activity to check their understanding before providing additional information and clarification on big ideas or patterns. 
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style FlowDirection="LeftToRight" LeadingMargin="0" TrailingMargin="0" FirstLineMargin="0" Justification="Left" CustomTabStops="" LineSpacingRule="Single" LineSpacing="20" SpacingBefore="0" SpacingAfter="0"> <ListStyle ListType="None" ListTypeFormat="Parentheses" Color="#000000" BulletFont="Arial" /> </Style> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style FlowDirection="LeftToRight" LeadingMargin="0" TrailingMargin="0" FirstLineMargin="0" Justification="Left" CustomTabStops="" LineSpacingRule="Single" LineSpacing="20" SpacingBefore="0" SpacingAfter="0"> <ListStyle ListType="None" ListTypeFormat="Parentheses" Color="#000000" BulletFont="Arial" /> </Style> <Span Text="All of your content exists within a context. Your course material has a wealth of research and history behind it that your students may not necessarily be aware of. While you don’t need to explain the beginning of numbers and letters, it may be useful to explain some of the background behind how a concept was discovered or created or what period of history the course material relates to. Providing additional information helps students lay a foundation of knowledge to build upon once they start using the skills and knowledge you want to teach them. You may also be able to ask students what they already know about a topic to activate their prior knowledge about the concept and build from there. Sometimes students know quite a bit about your topic and you can start at a higher level of discourse, rather than assuming students don’t know the basics. 
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style FlowDirection="LeftToRight" LeadingMargin="0" TrailingMargin="0" FirstLineMargin="0" Justification="Left" CustomTabStops="" LineSpacingRule="Single" LineSpacing="20" SpacingBefore="0" SpacingAfter="0"> <ListStyle ListType="None" ListTypeFormat="Parentheses" Color="#000000" BulletFont="Arial" /> </Style> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style FlowDirection="LeftToRight" LeadingMargin="0" TrailingMargin="0" FirstLineMargin="0" Justification="Left" CustomTabStops="" LineSpacingRule="Single" LineSpacing="20" SpacingBefore="0" SpacingAfter="0"> <ListStyle ListType="None" ListTypeFormat="Parentheses" Color="#000000" BulletFont="Arial" /> </Style> <Span Text="Click the X to return to the UDL slide. 
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style FlowDirection="LeftToRight" LeadingMargin="0" TrailingMargin="0" FirstLineMargin="0" Justification="Left" CustomTabStops="" LineSpacingRule="Single" LineSpacing="20" SpacingBefore="0" SpacingAfter="0"> <ListStyle ListType="None" ListTypeFormat="Parentheses" Color="#000000" BulletFont="Arial" /> </Style> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style FlowDirection="LeftToRight" LeadingMargin="0" TrailingMargin="0" FirstLineMargin="0" Justification="Left" CustomTabStops="" LineSpacingRule="Single" LineSpacing="20" SpacingBefore="0" SpacingAfter="0"> <ListStyle ListType="None" ListTypeFormat="Parentheses" Color="#000000" BulletFont="Arial" /> </Style> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style FlowDirection="LeftToRight" LeadingMargin="0" TrailingMargin="0" FirstLineMargin="0" Justification="Left" CustomTabStops="" LineSpacingRule="Single" LineSpacing="20" SpacingBefore="0" SpacingAfter="0"> <ListStyle ListType="None" ListTypeFormat="Parentheses" Color="#000000" BulletFont="Arial" /> </Style> <Span Text="Expression
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style FlowDirection="LeftToRight" LeadingMargin="0" TrailingMargin="0" FirstLineMargin="0" Justification="Left" CustomTabStops="" LineSpacingRule="Single" LineSpacing="20" SpacingBefore="0" SpacingAfter="0"> <ListStyle ListType="None" ListTypeFormat="Parentheses" Color="#000000" BulletFont="Arial" /> </Style> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style FlowDirection="LeftToRight" LeadingMargin="0" TrailingMargin="0" FirstLineMargin="0" Justification="Left" CustomTabStops="" LineSpacingRule="Single" LineSpacing="20" SpacingBefore="0" SpacingAfter="0"> <ListStyle ListType="None" ListTypeFormat="Parentheses" Color="#000000" BulletFont="Arial" /> </Style> <Span Text="Expression refers to the way students demonstrate their understanding and knowledge. It also includes the HOW of learning - HOW will students learn and provide evidence of their learning? 
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style FlowDirection="LeftToRight" LeadingMargin="0" TrailingMargin="0" FirstLineMargin="0" Justification="Left" CustomTabStops="" LineSpacingRule="Single" LineSpacing="20" SpacingBefore="0" SpacingAfter="0"> <ListStyle ListType="None" ListTypeFormat="Parentheses" Color="#000000" BulletFont="Arial" /> </Style> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style FlowDirection="LeftToRight" LeadingMargin="0" TrailingMargin="0" FirstLineMargin="0" Justification="Left" CustomTabStops="" LineSpacingRule="Single" LineSpacing="20" SpacingBefore="0" SpacingAfter="0"> <ListStyle ListType="None" ListTypeFormat="Parentheses" Color="#000000" BulletFont="Arial" /> </Style> <Span Text="Similar to using multiple means for presenting information, you may also consider using multiple mediums and media for communication. HCC students rarely respond to their emails, but they are much more likely to respond to direct messages on Canvas Inbox. You may also communicate with students through text, video, or audio announcements on Canvas, as well as reviewing important housekeeping items during class. Some students have also responded well to instructors who provide a Google Voice number that they can text since many students are more comfortable with their cell phones than they are with computers or laptops. Providing different avenues for students to communicate makes it more likely that students will reach out to you and respond when you reach out to them. 
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style FlowDirection="LeftToRight" LeadingMargin="0" TrailingMargin="0" FirstLineMargin="0" Justification="Left" CustomTabStops="" LineSpacingRule="Single" LineSpacing="20" SpacingBefore="0" SpacingAfter="0"> <ListStyle ListType="None" ListTypeFormat="Parentheses" Color="#000000" BulletFont="Arial" /> </Style> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style FlowDirection="LeftToRight" LeadingMargin="0" TrailingMargin="0" FirstLineMargin="0" Justification="Left" CustomTabStops="" LineSpacingRule="Single" LineSpacing="20" SpacingBefore="0" SpacingAfter="0"> <ListStyle ListType="None" ListTypeFormat="Parentheses" Color="#000000" BulletFont="Arial" /> </Style> <Span Text="Another important aspect of expression is providing opportunities for choice and autonomy. Instead of dictating the way that students must complete a project or assignment, provide a range of choices that students could use to demonstrate their learning. For example, instead of requiring all students to write a 4-page essay on the causes of the civil war, you could allow students to create a video, develop a podcast, create an infographic or create a presentation. All of these methods would allow you to evaluate students’ understanding of the causes of the civil war, but they would be free to choose the method of providing that evidence for themselves. This increases their autonomy and gives them the freedom to express their learning in the way that is most comfortable for them. Not everyone will choose to create a video and many students may still opt to write the traditional essay, but that’s their choice and it may make a big difference for the students who do opt for alternative formats. 
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style FlowDirection="LeftToRight" LeadingMargin="0" TrailingMargin="0" FirstLineMargin="0" Justification="Left" CustomTabStops="" LineSpacingRule="Single" LineSpacing="20" SpacingBefore="0" SpacingAfter="0"> <ListStyle ListType="None" ListTypeFormat="Parentheses" Color="#000000" BulletFont="Arial" /> </Style> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style FlowDirection="LeftToRight" LeadingMargin="0" TrailingMargin="0" FirstLineMargin="0" Justification="Left" CustomTabStops="" LineSpacingRule="Single" LineSpacing="20" SpacingBefore="0" SpacingAfter="0"> <ListStyle ListType="None" ListTypeFormat="Parentheses" Color="#000000" BulletFont="Arial" /> </Style> <Span Text="Students are not always able to accurately assess the amount of time and effort certain assignments will take and confusion and self-doubt often lead to putting things off until the last minute. You can help guide goal setting even for minor assignments by providing an estimated time students should expect to spend working on an assignment or reading. You can also help students evaluate their processes with self-reflection questions on how they approached the task and suggest more efficient ways to work. 
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style FlowDirection="LeftToRight" LeadingMargin="0" TrailingMargin="0" FirstLineMargin="0" Justification="Left" CustomTabStops="" LineSpacingRule="Single" LineSpacing="20" SpacingBefore="0" SpacingAfter="0"> <ListStyle ListType="None" ListTypeFormat="Parentheses" Color="#000000" BulletFont="Arial" /> </Style> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style FlowDirection="LeftToRight" LeadingMargin="0" TrailingMargin="0" FirstLineMargin="0" Justification="Left" CustomTabStops="" LineSpacingRule="Single" LineSpacing="20" SpacingBefore="0" SpacingAfter="0"> <ListStyle ListType="None" ListTypeFormat="Parentheses" Color="#000000" BulletFont="Arial" /> </Style> <Span Text="Scaffolding is a pedagogical term which means providing gradually declining support to help students complete a task. When a skill is brand new, students may need more support to get started on their own. Once they start to get the hang of it, you may need to provide nudges to keep them on course. Then when they are starting to master the skill, they may only need feedback after performance to help them achieve expert-level nuances in their work. Providing varying levels of support such as video tutorials, step-by-step guides and demonstrations can help give students the confidence they need to try skills on their own. Once they start getting good at it, you can back off a little and provide support only when needed. Providing support for students who need it and letting more proficient students work on their own helps you make the most efficient use of your time while also giving students the space or support they need to get the job done at their own pace. 
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style FlowDirection="LeftToRight" LeadingMargin="0" TrailingMargin="0" FirstLineMargin="0" Justification="Left" CustomTabStops="" LineSpacingRule="Single" LineSpacing="20" SpacingBefore="0" SpacingAfter="0"> <ListStyle ListType="None" ListTypeFormat="Parentheses" Color="#000000" BulletFont="Arial" /> </Style> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style FlowDirection="LeftToRight" LeadingMargin="0" TrailingMargin="0" FirstLineMargin="0" Justification="Left" CustomTabStops="" LineSpacingRule="Single" LineSpacing="20" SpacingBefore="0" SpacingAfter="0"> <ListStyle ListType="None" ListTypeFormat="Parentheses" Color="#000000" BulletFont="Arial" /> </Style> <Span Text="Click the X to return to the UDL slide. 
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style FlowDirection="LeftToRight" LeadingMargin="0" TrailingMargin="0" FirstLineMargin="0" Justification="Left" CustomTabStops="" LineSpacingRule="Single" LineSpacing="20" SpacingBefore="0" SpacingAfter="0"> <BaseSpanStyle FontFamily="Open Sans Semibold" FontSize="9" FontIsBold="False" FontIsItalic="False" FontIsUnderline="False" FontIsStrikeout="False" ForegroundColor="#000000" /> <ListStyle ListType="None" ListTypeFormat="Parentheses" BulletFont="Arial" /> </Style> </Block> </Content> </Document>

" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="
